title: 106_s1437
content: The Act may be cited as the "Thomas Jefferson Researcher's Privilege Act of 1999". It pertains to freedom of information requests. Section 552(b)(4) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include protection for data, records, or information related to academic, commercial, scientific, or technical research, including unpublished research notes and confidential information. The amendment to Section 552(b)(4) of title 5, United States Code provides protection for data, records, or information related to academic, commercial, scientific, or technical research, including unpublished research notes and confidential information that could impact the conduct or outcome of the research, future research likelihood, patent/copyright acquisition, or proprietary rights. SEC. 3. FEDERAL RULES OF CIVIL PROCEDURE. Rule 45(c)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is amended to require disclosure of data, records, or information collected in the conduct of study or research on academic, commercial, scientific, or technical issues, including unpublished research notes and confidential information. Rule 45(c)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is amended to require disclosure of data, records, or information related to research that could impact the conduct or outcome of the research, patents, copyrights, or proprietary rights. The amended Rule 45(c)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure mandates the disclosure of research-related information that could influence research conduct, outcomes, patents, copyrights, or proprietary rights, including unpublished research notes, data, processes, and confidential information. The amended Rule 45(c)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure requires disclosure of research-related information that could impact patents, copyrights, or proprietary rights. The Federal Rules of Evidence are addressed in Section 4. Rule 502 of the Federal Rules of Evidence grants a privilege for individuals engaged in academic, commercial, scientific, or technical research to refuse disclosure of confidential research information that could impact the research process or outcomes, patents, copyrights, or proprietary rights. SEC. 5. Repeal of requirement regarding data produced under federal grants and agreements awarded to institutions of higher education, hospitals, and other nonprofit organizations. The fifth and sixth provisos under the subheading "salaries and expenses" under the heading "OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET" under title III of the Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act, 1999 (Public Law 105-277; 112 Stat. 2681-495) are repealed.
